“What is unseemly and unprecedented is for the podium of the State Department to be hijacked for political theatrics.”

President Trump took fresh aim Thursday evening at former secretary of state John F. Kerry, accusing him of engaging in “illegal” meetings with an Iranian official.
Others who have criticized Kerry have suggested that he might have violated the Logan Act, which prohibits private citizens from negotiating on behalf of the U.S. government without authorization.
That statute requires those who represent the interests of foreign governments in a “political or quasi-political capacity” to disclose those relationships and details about their activities.
“I think everybody in the world is talking about waiting out President Trump,” said Kerry, a former senator from Massachusetts who was the 2004 Democratic presidential nominee.
“John Kerry had illegal meetings with the very hostile Iranian Regime, which can only serve to undercut our great work to the detriment of the American people,” Trump said.
“There’s nothing unusual, let alone unseemly or inappropriate, about former diplomats meeting with foreign counterparts,” spokesman Matt Summers said in a statement.
